item.title: Welcome
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to my new site.

Please excuse the mess while I get everything up and running.

item.title: Planning a vaction to Japan
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded: PLANNING THE TRIP I love history, so I knew I wanted to see definitely Tokyo, and Kyoto. If time, I also really wanted to see Hiroshima and Mount Fuji. My parents suggested Carlson Wagonlit, who had helped them in the past - the branch I visited specialized in Asia. The agent I was planning with had been there before so she had great advice based on my needs and her own experiences.  This was great is that because here were no pre-built tours. A magazine was provided that you can pick and choose to customize what you want to see. For Japan, the tour company in Japan was Sunrise Tours. The tours Are in English, and it seems like they are some available in other languages like Spanish. It is also helpful that some tours included the price of transit and meals. Check out the final trip itinerary they provided (please note pricing and tours may change or no longer be available). Important Notes: For any trip it is best to see a travel doctor to see what vaccines you need. Also, look into travel insurance. Be sure to check with your work to see if some insurance is included with your benefits. For example, I had medical insurance, so I bought a non-medical travel insurance package to supplement. Lastly, visit your government travel site. They will provide warning, and other information on places you visit, such as how cautious you need to be or other dangers.  The Canadian site also suggested to register the days and hotels you are staying at (as well as contact info). This is only used in emergencies or situations were you need to be evacuated or warned. SURVIVING A TEN HOUR FLIGHT Not wanting to miss connections or have trouble, I booked a non-stop flight. I brought a light weight laptop that had about six hundreds gigs (had my media libraries as well as room for storing digital photos). Power outlets were the same in Japan. It also helps to bring any media players or game consoles (like the DSi). A travel doctor suggested to bring some bottles of water, aspirin (due to sitting so long) and dry food to snack on. Also, you should do a circuit of the plane every few hours. this can help your circulation. And, you may need to advise the carrier if you have special meal requirements. More tips are on the Independent Traveler's Site. TRANSIT SITES TO USE Note: Tokyo transit systems have the fare based on distance traveled. The most useful site I found to use transit in Japan is hyperdia.com, it has routes, time tables, etc for all transit types (I wish I knew of this site before I went). Japan Rail Pass Information : This is for temporary visitors. It saves money on trains like the shinkansen. This must be bought BEFORE entry into Japan. Also, In Tokyo, pick up a 500¥ re-loadable card (the one I used was Pasmo). 2500¥ (about $25 CAN) got me the card and lasted for three quarters of my time in Tokyo (I only added more to get to the airport). COMMON PHRASES USED (very basic). (thing/place) wa doko desu ka? Where is the ______. at fast food places: (number from below)-ban kudasai. can I please have Number _____ (for example, Ordering a number 1 combo from McDonald - the only place open before 7 am in some places). See the below references for a useful travel phrase book, as well as a general guide on Japan. SAVE MONEY WHILE TRAVELING Quick note of approximate Yen (¥) to dollars (Canadian and United States). At the time of writing $1 = 80¥ (approx). Also, taxes is about 5% (based on Lonely Planet practical information). The easiest way to save money by traveling is to buy your meals from one of the many convenience stores. Most times you can get a full meal for about 500-700¥ (or $5-$7 in Canadian Currency). There are also small family owned shops if you do not buy meals from convenience stores. These stores have a curtain across part of the booth and what looks like a vending machine (it dispenses your order ticket) and are usually 900¥ or less. Buy a small container of laundry detergent before you go, some times can be washed in the sink. Wait as long as possible to buy souvenirs, and try to research beforehand, for items like electronics. Try using search engines or places like yahoo answers - there are many people who can tell the names of great stores or hidden locations. Use a travel card (such as Yak's) for emergencies, and try installing programs like Skype. Skype has pay as you go options, or monthly plans, and many hotels have free internet access, although, you may feel safer with a program like Netshade which can use vpn and proxy connections to protect yourself online. If you use a smart phone over seas, please be sure to turn on the roaming setting,and turn off data. REFERENCES AND MORE INFORMATION Lonely Planet Japanese Phrasebook Lonely Planet Japan Sunrise Tours Registration of Canadians Abroad Japan Travel Advice and Advisory from the Government of Canada

item.title: Bootstrap and asp.net 4.0 master pages
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
After some toiling and searching on line for a demo that includes asp.net inside a master page, I came across the blog post at geekswithblogs.net. However, the solution to use Resolve URL did not work correctly. After some debugging, I found a post at stack over flow using Script Manager. This finally allowed the jQuery and other scripts to work.

I have uploaded the code into my Github Repo, so hopefully someone will find this demo useful. I have also included the example from Twitter bootstrap called "Basic marketing site".

Please note this example uses web forms, and C#.

Update: Check out the demo: http://jenntes-demos.azurewebsites.net/

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks a lot! Muchas gracias! from Buenos Aires!

Hello,
I found this article by typing Bootstrap and ASP.net masterpages. Wanted to say thanks for the github example. I am creating a document that will help us extend our Bootstrap to meet branding guidelines. We are also looking at .LESS to piece together a modular CSS structure. My question is are you compling your CSS with LESS or are you using a static implementation of CSS??

Unfortunately, this is using the static bootstrap.css that came in the download. I will need to have a look at less to see how to integrate.
Edit: Perhaps this link will help? http://www.sitepoint.com/combining-less-with-asp-net/

item.title: Bootstrap and Google Maps API
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
This post contains some information and two samples of Bootstrap (modals) and Google maps. For both samples, stack overflow posts (below under resources) were of great assistance. I hope all these resources in one place will help someone else. UPDATE : November 5, 2013: A new post is available to demo Bootstrap 3 with Google Maps. October 26, 2013: After fixing the demos from moving hosts, I realized that the below demos will not work for the latest version of bootstrap. There will be a new post with updated code. In the mean time, please be aware that bootstrap 2.X is required. Demos:
  • Single Map
  • Many maps (using one modal)
  • Download Code
Resources
  • Address to Latitude and Longitude: enter a full address of the coordinates you wish to find, and press "go".
  • Stackoverflow posts: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8239372/google-maps-open-info-window-by-default http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11742839/showing-a-google-map-in-a-modal-created-with-twitter-bootstrap http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10626885/passing-data-to-a-bootstrap-modal/10635652#10635652 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8812268/grey-boxes-appear-in-parts-of-embedded-google-map-in-modal-box
  • Google maps in hidden div: shows to to fix improper cross browser display
Please let me know if I missed a resource, and I will add it here.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I need source code for Single Map ? Please send it to me. .
For the single map, just view the source code of the demo link: http://www.jenntesolin.com/demos/single-map.html Hope this helps.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Jennifer Tesolin's Blog | Bootstrap 3 and Google Maps
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] Note: This is an update to the older post using Bootstrap 2 with Google Maps. […]

item.title: Quick Tip: Wordpress and Campaign Monitor
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Just a quick and easy way to integrate your campaign monitor list. 

Step 1: Adding a subscribe form to your site

The easiest way, is to use the Wordpress text widget, and then paste in the campaign monitor built form code into it. To get a form, go to your list in campaign mointor, and click "Grow your audience". Next, click "Copy/paste a form to your site". Select the list(s) that you want, and then click generate code.  This will provide the form code to put into your blog. You can later customize the settings like email confirmation, thank you note, etc.

Step 2: Sending alert on Publish

As I am newer to Wordpress, I had to add the api wrapper into the themes directory to access. Now use the "create a draft campaign" and "Sending a draft campaign  to send an email. This code should go into a function like below:

function email_alert()  {
    //campaign monitor code
}
add_filter ( 'publish_post', 'email_alert' );

Resource:

Wordpress.org support: Publish actions

item.title: Installing Node JS and Grunt (on Mountain Lion)
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Node JS is a new generation of server side software. This tutorial focuses on installing the platform, and provides resources for using Grunt. Step 1: Download the latest stable binary from nodejs.org. At the time of writing its 0.10.5. For this tutorial, I just used the default settings Step 2: Verify your Path as per installer message: Make sure that /usr/local/bin is in your $PATH. Note: I found this post useful: architectryan.com/2012/10/02/add-to-the-path-on-mac-os-x-mountain-lion/. Please note to check that the path in the installer is shown in case it differs between versions. For my install, the oath was correctly set. GRUNT SET-UP Step 1: Installing Grunt on your machine globally. This section uses grunt 0.4.x This guide was made from referring to the official getting started documentation: http://gruntjs.com/getting-started. The sections referred to in this blog are: "Installing the CLI" and "Preparing a new grunt project". Grunt JS is installed by what node js refers to as NPM, or Node Package Manager. To install Grunt from NPM, you will need to use the command line. Type following command into the terminal: 
sudo npm install -g grunt-cli
Step 2: Create a package.json file go into your project directory, and run the below command. You can use the default settings, as the text file will be edited. My output is below. 
npm init
Open your favourite text editor, and edit the file "package.json" replace the text so it reads similar to teh below: 
{
  "name": "demo-project",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "author": "Jennifer Tesolin"
}
Now, using the terminal, run the below command in your project directory: 
npm install grunt --save-dev
npm install
This will install grunt into your locally in your package folder. If you open your package.json, you will find a new section added: 
,
"devDependencies": {
    "grunt": "~0.4.1"
 }
Associating plugins with Grunt/package.json Run the below command to use the plugin npm. 
npm install grunt-contrib --save-dev
Create your grunt file In your text editor, create a file called "Gruntfile.js" and save this into your project directory. A sample copy is below: 
module.exports = function(grunt) {

  // Project configuration.
  grunt.initConfig({

  });

  // Load call for plugins

  // Default task(s).

};
Check out the plugin's you can configure here: http://gruntjs.com/sample-gruntfile. Additional sources used For more grunt resources, check out the below. Google Chrome Grunt dev tools. A tutorial for getting started with Grunt for plugin section. "Developing with Grunt" by Dan Heberden (from jqueryTO conference): Audio | Slides. Meet Grunt: The Build Tool for JavaScript DailyJS: Backbone.js Tutorial: Build Environment

item.title: jQuery time picker issues and .net
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Recently I was wrestling with an issue with a time picker plugin not firing my custom validator onChange event. Here's the problem and how it was resolved.Our timepicker custom validation was not firing the onChange event. The following post from Stack overflow solved my problem:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8649565/do-not-fire-custom-validate-on-onchange-event-of-a-textbox

The problem was that for some reason it did not like control to validate. As suggested by the above post, using a validation group in my custom validation solved the issue.

item.title: iOS 7 wishlist
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Just a small post on what I would like to see in iOS. Videos:
  • bring back playlists
  • allow video playback when app minimized
  • allow others video apps to playback files that have DRM.
  • allow editing of tv episode date added, etc.
Built in apps:
  • give ability to turn off or hides apps like stocks, weather, contacts separate app (which is already in the phone portion)
  • move clock app to when you touch the time on screen
Camera roll:
  • Bulk delete pictures....enough said.
Books
  • In iTunes sync, button to uncheck/recheck all checkboxes

item.title: PHP and UTF8 encoding issues - tips and tricks to resolve
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Typically, having the proper character encoding on a page can be a bit of a pain, even if you have the right meta-tag. Here are some tips on how to ease the issue.

1. Add the following to the top of your php page:

ini_set('default_charset', 'UTF-8');
header('content-type: text/html; charset: utf-8');
mb_language('uni');
mb_internal_encoding('UTF-8');

2. Database in MySQL

Be sure that your databases in tables in mysql have a utf-8 correlation. This can be changed in phpMyAdmin under the options tab.

3. Make sure your MySQL query declares UTF-8

if ($db = @mysql_connect($host, $username, $password)) {
		mysql_select_db($databasename, $db);
		mysql_set_charset("utf8");
		mysql_query('SET NAMES utf8');
//code here
}

4. Make sure the php file is in UTF-8, not ASCII

Text editors such as sublime, can convert the page to UTF-8 for you, as post editors (and IDE's) may actually use ASCII. To convert the file to UTF-8 in sublime Text, go to file > Save with encoding > UTF-8.

Feel free to add more tips in the comments.

item.title: Wordpress Quicktip: Display x number of posts outside your blog.
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Sometime, you want to display posts outside of WordPress. Here are some resources to help.

From the Integrating WordPress in your Website codex file, the first place you start is to include a WordPress header file:

< ?php 
define('WP_USE_THEMES', false);
require('/the/path/to/your/wp-blog-header.php'); //found in the root of your WordPress install. 
?>

If you are using a multi-site blog, you will also need to add the below under the include:

switch_to_blog($blogID);

From the codex, the quickest example of showing a postis the following code:

$posts = get_posts('numberposts=10&order=ASC&orderby=post_title');
foreach ($posts as $post) : start_wp();
the_date(); echo "
";
the_title();    
the_excerpt();
endforeach;

Using the WPQuery function, you can target the number of days to show. The codex has the example code:

// Create a new filtering function that will add our where clause to the query
//from: http://codex.wordpress.org/Class_Reference/WP_Query#Time_Parameters
$args = array(
    'post_status' => 'publish'
);
function filter_where( $where = '' ) {
	// posts in the last 30 days
	$where .= " AND post_date > '" . date('Y-m-d', strtotime('-30 days')) . "'"; //change 30 to the number of days you want
	return $where;
}
add_filter( 'posts_where', 'filter_where' );
$query = new WP_Query( $args );
remove_filter( 'posts_where', 'filter_where' );

while ($query->have_posts()) {
   $the_query->the_post();
   echo '
  • ' . get_the_title() . '
    • ';
}

    Unfortunately, the number seemed to bit off. To fit it, I used the idea in the following post (StackOverflow) to add in my argument, -1. Now, your same code should be similar to below:

    //updated args
$args = array(
    'posts_per_page' => -1,
     'post_status' => 'publish'
);

    Full source code:

    < ?php 
define('WP_USE_THEMES', false);
require('/the/path/to/your/wp-blog-header.php'); //found in the root of your WordPress install.
switch_to_blog($blogID);
//updated args
$args = array(
    'posts_per_page' => -1,
     'post_status' => 'publish'
);
function filter_where( $where = '' ) {
	// posts in the last 30 days
	$where .= " AND post_date > '" . date('Y-m-d', strtotime('-30 days')) . "'"; //change 30 to the number of days you want
	return $where;
}
add_filter( 'posts_where', 'filter_where' );
$query = new WP_Query( $args );
remove_filter( 'posts_where', 'filter_where' );

while ($query->have_posts()) {
   $the_query->the_post();
   if (get_the_title()<>''){
      echo get_the_title().'
    ';
   }
}
?>

    Other Resources:

    StackExchange post
    Switch Blog in MultiSite

item.title: Great apps and programs for web development
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Below is a list of apps I use while working. While most have probably been seen before, I hope at least one is new. Please feel free to comment and add your favorite apps that you use for projects..... Does anyone else want a sublime or notepadd++ mobile app?

Cross Platform Apps

  • Source tree - source code app
  • Sublime - awesome text editor
  • Netbeans - an IDE, currently use it in a Java course

Windows Specific:

  • Notepad++
  • WinSCP

Mac Specific:

  • Code kit
  • Nettuts Apps
  • Fork Lift
  • Netshade: proxy tool

 Web Apps and automation:

  • Yeoman
  • Paste bin
  • YQL Development console: YQL is an awesome way to grab web site data and made cross domain requests using JSON. A tutorial is currently being written.

iOS apps:

  • JS anywhere
  • Pastebin
  • Evernote
  • Textastic

Guide:

  • Enabling built in Mountain lion web tools: PHP, MySQL, Apache
  • Apache Guide: First and most comprehensive guide to install Apache, MySQL, etc. Please note that while its a great guide, some of the versions may be out dated. Its always recommended to us ethe latest stable version.

item.title: What is YQL and how to you use it
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Yahoo Explains yql as: "an expressive SQL-like language that lets you query, filter, and join data across Web services. With YQL, apps run faster with fewer lines of code and a smaller network footprint.".  To get your feet feet with YQL, surf to the YQL Console. From here you can test queries and see the resulting rest Query (also listed on teh developer console, are premade requests from other Yahoo services such as flicker). In the "Your YQL statement" box, remove "Show tables" and type the below: 
select * from rss where url ="http://rss.cbc.ca/lineup/technology.xml"
In the text area beside the JSON radio button, replace “cbfunc” with “?” and uncheck Diagnostics. Once this is completed, click “TEST”. Copy the rest query from the "Rest Query" text input field. For the above example, my rest query is: 
http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=select%20*%20from%20rss%20where%20url%20%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Frss.cbc.ca%2Flineup%2Ftechnology.xml%22&format=json&callback=?
Note: the rest query has a secure option. Just change "http" to "https". A screenshot of the output is below: The jQuery Call Unfortunately, my blog keeps removing my html entries, so please feel free to download the source code to view the demos.  Sorry, these for some reason were not brought with the move. They will be restored as soon as possible.
  1. Using the count yql json element to determine how many to display
  2. Display many entries
Last note: When using jQuery, date functions do not work cross browser. For these functions, please consider using a library such as Moment.js. Resources: Wikipedia Page YQL Developers Site YQL Console DEVELOPER's Guide NetTuts+ resources IBM examples JQuery getJson More on noConflict

item.title: Quick Tips: Firefox and Notepad++
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
This posting is just to highlight some tips and tricks I found while working on sites.

Firefox

While working, I came across a portion of my work where I wanted to disable JavaScript. Usually in Firefox, I can go to the preferences > General then uncheck JavaScript, however, this option was removed in the latest beta of Firefox. After searching on the Mozilla wiki, I would that you need to toggle a setting in your about:config. Filter for: JavaScript.enabled then set to false to disable JavaScript.

Notepad++

There is a neat trick - if you select an tag or a word in your file and press control and left or right key (test in windows), your cursor will automatically be moved too next tag or word. Control up and down will scroll view up and down.

Hope someone will find these useful. Please feel free to leave your tips or tricks below.

item.title: New Github Commit
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
BootstrapPHP-imdbSearch: a demo built of that uses the IMDB API from mymovieapi.com. This code is using PHP5 and Simple XML as the backend. The front end is created using bootstrap. The folder structure on your server should be: Web Root
- index.php - imdb.php /css /fonts
In other words, move files out of the app folder. View repo: https://github.com/jennifert/Bootstrap-imdbSearch View demo site: http://jenntesolin.com/demos/Bootstrap-IMDB/index.php demos/ There will be a follow-up post in the future for a version using JavaScript instead of PHP.

item.title: Quick tips: MySql Case
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
There was a table that had different spellings for titles in between male and female titles. However, I did not want to spend too much time programming in the application itself. I stumbled upon the mysql case:

Case When table1.Gender = 'Female' Then table1.ftitlesfr When table1.Gender = 'Male' Then table1.mtitlesfr End AS titlesfr

You the above in place of a field name as such:.

SELECT table1.name, table1, table1.titleen, Case When table1.Gender = 'Female' Then table1.ftitlesfr When table1.Gender = 'Male' Then table1.mtitlesfr End AS titlesfr FROM table1

 Hope this helps someone else!

item.title: Quick Tip: MySQL Concat
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
While working on a project, I was looking for a way to join to mysql columns without using php or .net. I came across the concat function. It basically allows you to join together 2 columns as one.

Here is the code:

SELECT CONCAT(firstname, ' ', lastname) As fullname FROM table1 ....

Hope it helps someone.

item.title: Move completed.
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded: The web server move has been completed. Please let me know in the comments, or content page if any issues appear. All links from the old domain should automatically redirect to the new domain. Lastly, server is now enabled for PHP 5.4, and using a localized version of WordPress - English Canada.

item.title: A look at Raspmbc video streaming
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
The Raspberry Pi Foundation described the pi as "The Raspberry Pi is a credit-card sized computer that plugs into your TV and a keyboard. It’s a capable little PC which can be used for many of the things that your desktop PC does, like spreadsheets, word-processing and games. It also plays high-definition video.". This post is to assist in setting up your Raspberri Pi With an XMBC build called Raspmbc. Choosing the Modal If you are going to be doing video streaming (especially over HDMI), it is recommended to buy the Version B. This is because. the modal has more memory than previous model, and has better video streaming. It can be purchased at any of the following sites:
  • Amazon.ca
  • Element 14
  • RS
  • Also, be sure to check your local computer shop. While these are currently not being sold in big box stores, other smaller computer shops may have some in.
Storage/Operating System "Drive" This mini computer does not have a traditional hard drive. Instead, it uses SD cards to house the operating system. It is also recommended to pick up a class 10 SD card (if you do not opt for the noob package). If your just using the machine for streaming, an 8 GB one should suffice, otherwise I believe the highest supported is 32 GB. Like me, you may have luck finding the other components needed to use the device around your house - the key is to mix and match. For example,  I found an old mini USB cable to USB port from an old hard drive, then connected that to my iPhone USB to wall plug (but for safely, when not in use, I power down the machine). Here is a list of all components. Analog Tv Use:
  • Composite video cable
  • RCA audio cable
With HDMI:
  • HDMI cable only
  • HDMI (to __ device sold separately)
Everything:
  • Ethernet cable or Wireless USB
  • MicroUSB Cord
  • Optional: Usb to wall outlet
First step install raspmbc on your card. Adding Raspmbc to your SD Card: Windows or Os X/Linux. Now, plug your ad card into the slot on your Pi, and let it run. For some reason it did no like the mouse, so I went through the install steps with just a keyboard - USB worked great after. Now, for initial set-up, its recommended to use ssh to make initial configurations. Initial commands to run in remote computer ssh (in order) sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get upgrade sudo apt-get install ffmpeg Optional Add your license keys to config.txt. Some other settings to tweak on raspmbc are: Video resolution: Settings > System > Video Output > Resolution Over clock: rograms > Raspbmc Settings > System Configuration > System Performance Profile > Fast Enable airplay: System > Network > “Allow XBMC to receive AirPlay content Turn of thumbnails: Settings > Video > File lists > disable “Extract thumbnail and video information” Use eBook to explain how to connect Mac, Linux, Window's share. Set-up PlayOn Unfortunately, plex media centre did not work with my set up, so for Netflix and other channels, I used playOn. It was around $50 (CAD) (about 30 US) and can works well in an xp virtual machine. I recommend testing only my media (free) before purchasing. The below is based on playOn's parallel's guide. Need: VMware Fusion (be sure to update software) Feel free to try virtualbox, which is free virutaliztation software. Hotspot Shield (for outside of US) Set up Virtual Machine:
  1. Create an XP machine with 2GB RAM in "bridge Networking - Auto-detect" Mode and a static virtual disk (not expanding). Use at least a 16GB virtual disk. Playon Suggests utilizing 2 cores to stream.
  2. Once XP is loaded, uninstall everything you don't need (MSN Browser, paint, games, etc.).
  3. Right click on "My computer", select Advanced settings - and set your settings to "Best performance"
  4. Install the latest service packs and windows updates
  5. Stop and disable indexing service.
  6. Install PlayOn with default settings.
  7. Restart your machine
Enable in Raspmbx:
  1. Basic: Files > Add Videos… > Browse > UPnP Devices > PlayOn... > OK
  2. Advanced (seamless channels): http://mymediaexperience.com/integrate-netflix-and-hulu-into-xbmc/
Optional: Once it works with "myMedia", stop playOn, and install Hotspot Shield into the virtual server. Restart your machine, and try the settings. If everything works and you like the product, purchase a full license. That's it. Hope it helps someone. Resources for this post and further research
  • Book: Raspberri Pi: Media Centre
  • Equipment
  • Quick start guide
  • FAQ
  • Rasplex
  • Raspmbc
  • Setting up a Raspberry Pi as an XBMC Device using RaspBMC
  • Discussion: Netflix on Raspbmc
  • The Raspberry Pi Home Theater: What You Can And Cannot Do
  • Raspmbc add on: plexmbx
  • PlayOn: For RaspMBC netflix and hulu Streaming (without Plex)
  • RaspMBC set-up Guide
  • Create a Kickass, Seamless, Play-Everything Media Center: The Complete Guide

item.title: Raspberry Pi: List of Projects and resources
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
This post contains a list of resources and tips and tricks found while putting together my Raspmbc media centre.  Please note all links below are leaving this site. Raspberry PI Info
  • RaspberryPi.org
  • Equipment
  • Quick start guide
  • RPI Hub
Other Guides

  • Raspberry Pi: Project listings

  • Air Video Server - Stream Video to IPad

Troubleshooting

item.title: Quick Tip: MySql Replace
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
While looking for ways to improve my MySQL queries, I can across the REPLACE function. Example code: Select Statement: 
SELECT field1,
      REPLACE(yourstring, 'searchfor', 'stringtoreplacewith' ) AS field2,
      field3
FROM testdb
Update Statement: 
UPDATE testDB2
SET aColumn = REPLACE (aColumn, 'searchfor', 'stringtoreplacewith')
WHERE id=1
Hope this helps someone. References: Stackoverflow Post: MySQL string replace

item.title: Bootstrap 3 and Google Maps
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
There are changes in Bootstrap 3 that stops google maps from displaying correctly in modals, or tabs.  New demos have been created to show to to utilize in your code. Single Map: http://jenntesolin.com/demos/single-map_bootstrap3.html Multi-Map: http://jenntesolin.com/demos/multi-map_bootstrap3.html Download Code To use in a tab, change the following: 
$("#mapModal").on("shown.bs.modal", function () {
to 
$("#mapTab").on("shown.bs.tab", function () {
Also, in the modal the "hide" class, as well as other changes as per Bootstrap Documentation. Note: This is an update to the older post using Bootstrap 2 with Google Maps. Resources: Google Maps in Navbar in Bootstrap 3 Bootstrap Documentation: V3 Bootstrap Documentation: Modals

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Jennifer Tesolin's Blog | Bootstrap and Google Maps API (V3)
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] November 5, 2013: A new post is available to demo Bootstrap 3 with Google Maps. […]

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Jennifer Tesolin's Blog | Using Require JS with Bootstrap, Google maps, and more
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] Works off previous Post: Bootstrap 3 and Google Maps […]

Thanks for these examples. Especially the multi map solution.
BTW Noticed that in both examples the div ID is map_canvas and the styling rules use #map-canvas.

Ignore that nonsense above please. I have read things, and that is just nonsense!
Sorry.

item.title: Quick Tip: Using Font Awesome With Bootstrap 3
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
This is a quick post on how to use Font Awesome with Bootstrap 3. To use font-awesome, you will need to have a customized version of the latest version of Bootstrap 3 "Without icons". This can be done via the Customize Bootstrap page or from the bootstrap cdn. Option 1A: Bootstrap CDN: 
http://netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.0.0/css/bootstrap.no-icons.min.css
Option 1B: Downloading from Bootstrap: Under "LESS files" > "Components" (middle column) > Uncheck "Glyphicons". Enter in any other information (or remove JS not being used, and then scroll to the bottom of the page and click "Compile and download". Option 2A: Font Awesome CDN: 
//netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/font-awesome/4.0.3/css/font-awesome.css
Option 2B: Downloading from font awesome Go to fontawesome.io, then click the "Download" button on the front page. Code/Demo:
  • View demo
  • Download now
Note: The latest version does not work in Internet explorer 7 or lower. Resources: Bootstrap 3: forms Font-Awesome: Examples Found CDN for n icons from github Issue Post. Bootstrap CDN

item.title: Using Require JS with Bootstrap, Google maps, and more
item.dc:creator: jenntes

item.title: Asp.net menu control - styling with bootstrap nav
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Thanks to an interesting post titled "Responsive ASP.NET Menu Control With Twitter Bootstrap", I was able to update the Bootstrap with master pages example with asp.net menu controls instead of being hard coded.

For the menu control, you basically add the below code in lace of the div with "nav-collapse collapse". The menu in this code is based off the Bootstrap Example "Basic marketing site".

Here is a link to the raw code in GitHub. It starts at line 43.

The one downside to the menu control is that the control will inject inline styles.  Also, to display the search form in the menu bar, use the code from the bootstrap documentation, then change the <form> to a <span>.

Before:

<form class="navbar-search pull-left">
<input type="text" class="search-query" placeholder="Search">
</form>

After:

<span class="navbar-search pull-left">
<input type="text" placeholder="Search">
</span>

Thank you so much for your help.
Andry

item.title: Quick Tip: Fixing Ubuntu 12.04 network issue
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
While upgrading an Ubuntu virtual machine from Version 10 LTs to 12.04 LTS, I ran into networking issues with the static IP address and DNS servers. The web server was accessible on the network, however, the virtual machine was not able to ping google, or download any updates. Errors encountered with this issue:
  • waiting for 60 more seconds for ...
  • Booting without full network capability
  • Network .... not compatible with this version of Ubuntu.
To fix this, I first I tried reconfiguring the networking, then adding DNS servers into the network interfaces with no luck. Also, tried editing various files mentioned in other posts. Finally I ran across a post from Ask Ubuntu Forums.  So, here are the steps mentioned to resolve this issue:
  1. Create a copy of the following file: /etc/network/interfaces:
    sudo cp /etc/network/interfaces /etc/network/iBKUp
  2. Edit the network interface file as root:
    sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces
  3. Make sure the file only has the following:
    auto lo iface lo inet loopback
  4. Reboot the machine
After these steps, the machine will hopefully boot normally and the networking centre should have resolved itself as well. In the Network centre, you re-add the static IP information into your wired connection and lastly reboot again. Hope this helps others!

item.title: Quick Tip: Wordpress Development Tips
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded: 1. Stop wordpress updater by ftp. As per the following post, "Wordpress needs access to your web server", you can prevent work press for asking for your ftp credentials when requesting an update. Add the below lines to your wp.config.php file. .... $method = 'direct'; define('FS_METHOD','direct'); /* That's all, stop editing! Happy blogging. */ ... 2. Fix any issues with your (or another) plugin There is a great plugin called "Log Deprecated Notices" that aids in Wordpress development. Just turn change WP_DEBUG to 'true" and download the latest version from the above link. Once installed, it will be under: Tools > Deprecated Calls. The deprecated call and line number will be displayed, along with an alternative to fix. Note: This was only performed on a development machine. It is only recommended to do the above in a development environment.

item.title: Setting up Bluetooth on the raspberry pi
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
Setting up a bluetooth dongle can be quite interesting when using Raspmbc. Here is a guide on setting up. Requirements:
  • Raspberry pi
  • Bluetooth dongle (I used this one from ModMyPi)
  • Wifi or ethernet connected
Steps: I found the following guide very helpful, however kept running into errors. To fix it, run the following command after rebooting and before in place of installing bluetooth: apt-get install obex-data-server apt-get ​install bluetooth bluez-utils blueman bluez-compat If you have tried in the past to install bluetooth, but its still broken, run the below command: sudo dpkg --configure -a Unfortunately, there where problems pairing the device with the error message being: 
Creating device failed: org.bluez.Error.AuthenticationRejected: Authentication Rejected
So following another article, it is recommended to type in: sudo nano /usr/bin/bluez-simple-agent Now, in this file, change 'KeyboardDisplay' with 'DisplayYesNo'. Resources
  • Step by step Guide for setting up keyboard and mouse on Pi
  • Bluetooth keyboard on the Pi.
Note: Some bluetooth items will not work on Raspmbc such as audio. It has been suggested (Raspberry pi official forums) to instead use OpenELEC or Xbian.

item.title: Moving from an iOS Device to Android (iCloud)
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded: Admittedly moving from an iOS device to an android device can seem a bit daunting, especially if you use iCloud for all your syncing. Thankfully there are a few apps on the Google play store that help connect your droid to icloud! Note: Please be sure to read reviews before download the apps from the store. These have been found while doing research for a new smart phone purchase. I do not have a droid to test on currently. SmoothSync for Cloud Calendar Syncs: calendars and reminders Store Link: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.dmfs.caldav.icloud Description from Store: SmoothSync for Cloud Calendar syncs your iCloud calendars and reminders. Due to its implementation as sync adapter it integrates seamlessly with the native calendar app and widgets and operates invisible in the background. Reminder For iCloud/iOS/iPhone Syncs: Reminders Store Link: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=us.doplus.reminder Description from Store: This is a sole Android to-do reminder app that sync with Reminders of iCloud (iOS/Mac). All you have to do is creating a reminder on your phone and it will reminder you at the right time so that you won't miss any important task. It is designed to sync with the Reminder of iCloud. So, an iCloud account is needed before using this application. iNotes - Sync Note with iOS Syncs: notes Store Link: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.dayup.inotes Description from Store: iNotes is an easy notes app for synchronizing your notes of Android to Notes app on Mac/iOS(iphone, ipad) . It is currently applicable to iCloud, Gmail,Yahoo, Aol,163 only. SmoothSync for Cloud Contacts Syncs: Contacts Store Link: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.dmfs.carddav.icloud Description from Store: SmoothSync for Cloud Contacts syncs your iCloud contacts. Due to its implementation as sync adapter it integrates seamlessly with the native contacts app and operates invisible in the background. iCloud Mail Sync App: Blue Mail - Email & Mailboxes Store Link: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.trtf.blue Description from Store: Blue Mail is a free and universal email client allowing you to use and manage as many email accounts as you desire at the same time to create a powerful Unified Inbox experience with an extraordinary and modern design. Blue Mail supports Gmail, Yahoo, Office 365, AOL, Google Apps, Hotmail, Outlook, iCloud, Mail.ru, Zoho, GMX and any other IMAP mailbox! Alternative Option - Imap settings for icloud: https://discussions.apple.com/thread/3636567?start=15&tstart=0 iCloud HD Syncs: seems to be a portal for icloud site (on tablets only) Store Link: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.datheuma.icloud Description from Store: We present to you iCloud on Android. Access the iCloud control panel from the comfort of your Android tablet. Use your iCloud login and password to log in and you are ready to go. Bonus: Airplay Apps for Android The following site has reviews on various airplay apps: http://www.knowyourmobile.com/android-apps/18049/best-airplay-apps-android-gettin-dream-stream Bonus: iCloud Bookmarks (iOS, PC and Mac Only) Syncs: bookmarks (note untested on mobile android) Store Link: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/icloud-bookmarks/fkepacicchenbjecpbpbclokcabebhah?hl=en Description from Store: iCloud stores your website bookmarks, so they are everywhere you go — on your iPhone, iPad, iPod touch, Mac, and PC. So when it comes to your devices, you can switch things up without mixing things up.

item.title: Upcoming Github Updates
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
A frequently updated list of outstanding items to be added to the github repos. Google Maps:
  • Try examples using font awesome in pop up box. Also try require js if successful on first attempt.
PHP Auction site
  • *email functionality (phase 1: user account info, phase 2: bid posted,profile changed, )
  • stronger password security and/or OAuth/twitter/facebook/google login.
  • replace icons with font awesome (and possibly utilize google fonts or type kit)
  • adding require js
  • adding a map to show "pick-up" location. Will need to update DB (item)
  • add more variable checks in php and some in JS.
  • upgrading to latest version of bootstrap.
  • countdown to auction close (Moment.JS)
  • password show/hide similar to iOS devices, strength meter
  • a way to change your password.
  • a profile
Bootstrap Master Pages:
  • link all pages together
  • add demo in azure to the read me file
  • Check bootstrap snipes for ideas.
Bootstrap movie search:
  • Fix poster image (use a google query if needed)
  • look into way to see if its playing anywhere
  • use location api to get info
  • get log/lat and search google maps
  • link to youtube for easy access trailers or see if they can be puled from imdb.
  • Make sure that user input is using latest tech and checks.
  • will become part of a library service or management system.
  • add client side validation before submit.

item.title: Creating the Sticky footer with fixed navbar example with Bootstrap 3 using Emmet.IO
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
This post described how to use Emmet short codes to quickly create the bootstrap example: Sticky footer with fixed navbar using Bootstrap 3. Feel free to read and implement suggestions.

In Sublime, select the Emmet code and press control + E (both Mac and PC)

Step 1: Set up: Set up html, and body content, js

A) Emmet Code

html:5>(div.navbar.navbar-default.navbar-fixed-top>div.container>div.navbar-header>btn:r.navbar-toggle>span.sr-only{Toggle navigation}+span.icon-bar+span.icon+span.icon^a.navbar-brand{Welcome!}^div.collapse.navbar-collapse>ul.nav.navbar-nav>li*3>a^li.dropdown>a.dropdown-toggle{Dropdown }>b.caret^ul.dropdown-menu>li*3>a^li.divider+li.dropdown-header{Nav Header}+li*3>a^^^^^^^div.container>div.page-header>h1{Page Header Heer}^p.lead>lorem^^div#footer>div.container>p.text-muted{Copy Right Info}^^script:src{js/jquery-1.11.0.min.js}+script:src{js/bootstrap.min.js})

Gist Location: https://gist.github.com/jennifert/9846832

Note: Could not find emmet tag to define javascript source location, so just moved it between script tags. Please see step 8 at 1B below.

B) Fill in the missing items/editing places:

1) Add role=navigation to : navbar.navbar-default.navbar-fixed-top
2) At the toggle navigation <button> add: data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".navbar-collapse"
3) Add link # or otherwise at: navbar-brand
4) Add link, text and active item to: nav.navbar-nav remove
5) In same class as above but in dropdown dropdown-toggle, add data-toggle="dropdown"
6) Edit h1 tag in: page-header class div
7) Update Copy right Info
8) Move js path that's between script tags to src=""

Step 2: Insert the rest of the header information

A) Emmet Code: Place course on line under <title>...</title>

meta:vp+link:favicon+meta:compat+link:css{css/bootstrap.min.css}+link:css

Gist Location: https://gist.github.com/jennifert/9846855

B) Edit the following items:
1) Favicon.ico if needed
2) Change ie=7 to ie=edge in meta tag.
3) In the style.css where you bootstrap is nested in, cut and paste the bootstrap stylesheet in place of styles.css.
4) In between the updated bootstrap css and styles.css, paste your conditional comments.

<!--[if lt IE 9]>
<script src="https://oss.maxcdn.com/libs/html5shiv/3.7.0/html5shiv.js"></script>
<script src="https://oss.maxcdn.com/libs/respond.js/1.4.2/respond.min.js"></script>
<![endif]-->

5) In the file styles.css paste the bootstrap example styles from: http://getbootstrap.com/examples/sticky-footer-navbar/sticky-footer-navbar.css

item.title: Removing cData from YQL queries
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
When pulling data from xml items using YQL and getJSON, your application will unfortuntley not parse tags that have cdata. This post describe show to use the feed normalizer table to call all elements, even those that have cdata.

YQl Feed Normalizer

To use this table in my application, I worked off of the second example given on the YQL blog entry: SELECT * FROM feednormalizer WHERE url='http://rss.news.yahoo.com/rss/topstories' AND output='atom_1.0' Note: the portion in bold beside the url is where your atom feed will go. Here is a list of valid outputs for the second bold portion: 'rss_0.91N'|'rss_0.93'|'rss_0.92'|'rss_1.0'|'rss_0.94'|'rss_2.0'|'rss_0.91U\rss_0.9'|'atom_1.0'|'atom_0.3'

Final Code

Now, I added limit after the output field, and replaced * with the fields I wanted. The bold portions are the portions I personalized for my site. YQL : SELECT entry.title,entry.link.href,entry.published,entry.category.term,entry.summary FROM feednormalizer WHERE url= "http://jenntesolin.com/blog/feed/atom/" AND output="atom_1.0" LIMIT 1

The full javaScript: //declare vars
var blogLink = 'https://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=' + encodeURIComponent('SELECT entry.title,entry.link.href,entry.published,entry.category.term,entry.summary FROM feednormalizer WHERE url= "http://jenntesolin.com/blog/feed/atom/" AND output="atom_1.0" LIMIT 1')+'&format=json&diagnostics=false&callback=?';
//end variable declare

jQuery.noConflict();
jQuery(document).ready(function($){

//Call blog feed
$.getJSON(blogLink, function(data){
//get data
var title =data.query.results.feed.entry.title.content;
var link =data.query.results.feed.entry.link.href;
var category =data.query.results.feed.entry.category.term;
var published=data.query.results.feed.entry.published;
var summary =data.query.results.feed.entry.summary.content;

//display
$('.blog-header').html(title);
$('.blog-summary').html(summary);
$('.blog-date').html(published);
$('.blog-category').html(category);
$('.blog-link').html('<a href="'+link+'" target="_blank">Read more</a>');
});
//end blog feed
}); HTML Bootstrap 3.1 code <!-- Blog -->
<div class="row">
<div class="col-md-12">
<h1 class="blog-header"></h1>
<p class="blog-summary"></p>
<div>
<span class="badge blog-date"></span>
<div class="pull-right">
<span class="label label-default blog-category"></span>
<span class="label label-primary blog-link"></span>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- /.Blog --> Resources YQL Feed Normalizer Table Code on GitHub Demo

item.title: Updated: Raspberry Pi Media Server
item.dc:creator: jenntes
item.content:encoded:
After trying quite a few Raspberry Pi operating systems and configurations, the new RasPlex is my choice for my home media centre. RasPlex was the best system which supports out of the box: WiFi, Bluetooth, hdmi monitor with analog speakers, and more. The best thing is the entire process took only 15 minutes!

Note: This is an update to the Raspmbc set-up article. RasPlex also requires the use of Plex Media Server which is also free, and easily connects to iTunes and various channels.

Set-up the SD card

The first step is to download the installer for your Operating System onto your computer. They have installers available for Mac, Linux, and Windows, please be sure to read the notes on how to mount the installer.

Now, you select the version of RasPlex you want, and then select your SD card drive (check disk utility for the name if your not sure). Finally, press "update links", and when that is down "click download".  It will ask you the location of the download, then when will display the download progress in the terminal. Once your all set-up, then press "Write SD card".

 

Set-Up your Raspberry Pi

Make sure all your devises (even Bluetooth and Wi-Fi) are connected, then boot your machine. Let it run the initial set-up, and reboot itself.

Once it reboots, follow the on screen instructions for set-up (note that only your keyboard will work so far). Some of the set-up options include: Bluetooth, WI-Fi, your Plex Media Server.

When you see the menu, press the left keyboard arrow to get to your settings, this is where you can set-up your audio settings, ssh access, and more. At set-up it will choose HDMI audio, just select analog to use stereo speakers.

That's it! This this helps other people as well.

RasPlex Resources:

  • RasPlex Github Guides Pages
  • RasPlex Set-Up Basics Documentation Page

Check out their YouTube Trailer (it tells it better than me)
